titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the David and Gideon Kimberly papers 1977.020
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

did.abstract: This collection contains deeds, bonds, and letters spanning the period 1788 to 1845. Included are 46 letters to creditor David Kimberly (1785-1861) dating from 1839 and 1845, most from several Southern cotton growers asking for more time to pay debts due to a poor cotton crop. There are also five bankruptcy notices to David Kimberly dating from 1841 to 1842; four legal documents of the estate of Gideon Kimberly dating from 1819 to 1821; one letter from Amos Kimberly to his cousin, dated 1833; two deeds from 1788 and 1796; and one bond from 1802.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: David Kimberly (1785-1861), a merchant, entered the New York City business of his uncle, Gideon Kimberly, in 1800, and became a partner in 1813. In 1839, David Kimberly was also a creditor who held the notes for several Southern cotton growers. Both David and Gideon Kimberly resided in Brooklyn.
